captions.text: (TL;DR Music)

(A TUBA GOES: DA DA DA DA DA DA DA 
 DA, DA DA DA DA DA DA DA DA)

(TUBA, SYNTH GO: DA DA DA DA DA DA DA 
 DA, DA DA DA DA DA DA DA DA)

[M] Dhyphlnis from Singapore asks, [S] "What's the funniest/most 
 awkward conversation you guys had with Koreans?

[M] This was actually a little bit of 
 a difficult question for us to answer
because  we really haven't had very many awkward conversations. [S] That's right.

[M] Yeah, even if our Korean is really limited 
 and the person's English is really limited,

we like, hand signal and flail like we're in a puppet show. 
 [S] We find a way to come to middle ground
and communicate with each other.
[M] Yeah, so it's never really been that awkward,

but... I think we can think of just a 
 couple of situations where something went terribly wrong.
[S] There are some golden moments. [M] Yes.

[S] So the situations we're about to relate to, aren't 
 really mistranslations as much as they are just awkward.

[M] How about you dancing around with no pants because you lost them in 
 super slow motion? (Cue Simon and Martina's version of EXO's "What is love")

[S] That's not awkward, that's brilliant. [M] That's pretty 
 awkward. I'm like, where are your pants?

And you're like, I lost them in super slow motion. 
(I 
 lost my pants In Ripito Fipito Sipi Slow Motion)

[S] Look. How many of you now have sung that when 
 you lost your pants? (In Ripito Fipito Sipi Slow Motion)

Raise your hand if you lost your pants. Hands up, I 
 see you there. (Martina raises hand) That's right missy.
[M] Okay, so backstory behind this before I actually start explaining my story.

Awhile ago, we did a "Korean Like a Pro" video, 
 where Simon was dressed up like a Korean guy

and came up to me wiggling his eyebrows and asked me if I 
 was Russian... that's right. [S] "Russian Saram? Russian Saram? Russian Saram."

So basically, if somebody asks you where you're from, it's a lot different 
 than if an old Korean guy walks up to you and says,
"Are you a Russian person?" That has a completely different meaning here in Korea:

it's insinuating the question of, are you a prostitute? And, 
 can we make a 'boom boom giggity giggity' together?

[M] Do you mean like play checkers? [S] 
 If that's what you call it nowadays.

[M] Hopscotch? [S] Think of it like 'Leap Frog' except you are stuck on the person, 
 you can't get over them, not that you are necessarily trying to do so.

[M] So, like you're tied to the person with 
 ropes or something? (the sound of crickets chirping)

[S] That's a possibility if you're into that.
[M] Kind of 
 like 'Capture the Flag' but with two people?

So essentially what happened was, it was the wintertime and 
 I was wearing a ginormous, puffy, feather filled jacket.

Totally sexy as you might imagine in your head, and I was sitting 
 on a bench waiting for Simon to meet up with me.

And as I was sitting there, bundled up to the nostrils in all types of 
 winter clothing, an old man came up to me and sat down beside me.
And turned to me and said, "Russian Saram?" with the eyebrow wiggles.
So I immediately gave him the extremely cold shoulder and said, "No, I'm Canadian."

and I said it in Korean very clearly, but he insisted that 
 I must have been somehow pretending that I was Russian.
So, again he was like, "Oh, aniyo Russian Saram?"

And so, I emphasized again: "Not only am I Canadian, but I'm also married, 
 and my husband is coming here." And, I showed him my ring.

Which, he still didn't believe me. So then, I got to the point 
 where I had to pull out my handphone, (For your information: Handphone=cellphone)

and show him the Canadian flag, which I had actually requested from 
 the Canadian embassy for being called Russian so many times.

Still, he didn't get the hint. Then he asks me, if 
 I want to go get some food to eat.
Finally I had to turn around extremely rudely and say to him,

"I'm not Russian, I'm Canadian. I don't want food. 
 I'm married. I have a husband. Get lost.

[S] How do you say get lost in Korean? 
 [M] Naga! [S] Naga! 
[M] Like, get out!

Finally, it took Simon showing up from the bus stop, and me 
 like, bounding up to Simon like a happy happy bunny.

And the guy finally left. [S] And then it was really awkward when I 
 picked up the subway cart, and then I threw it at him.

And then there was a police investigation afterwards.
[M] Dunnnn,dun dun dun dunnnnn.

[S] And we're actually wanted now in Korea after 
 the death of a perverted, old man.
[M] Now, Simon's story, which seems to be a similar vein somehow.

[S] Back when I was a teacher, I always had 
 during my lunch breaks an open classroom policy.

And, I would let students come in there and 
 try to practice their English through conversation.
Now, these conversations weren't meant to be formal about the textbook stuff.

It was all meant to be casual, you know, just slang 
 here, and talking about the day and stuff like that.

Now, the kids that most often came to my class were the ones that 
 were really rambunctious in class and didn't really pay a lot of attention.

But they were actually really good kids at heart: they would 
 always come at lunch and want to chat with me.

Anyhow, one of these days, during one of these conversations at lunch, 
 they all came together, and they started talking about girlfriends.

They all started laughing and pointed to one guy 
 and they said, "Teacher. He has a girlfriend."

And I'm like,"That's good for you. Fantastic! You know, I'm happy that you have 
 a girlfriend outside of class, and your life isn't just dedicated to studying."
And then they all started going, "Teacher. Oh yeah."

And I didn't really understand what this is. What is this 
 motion?
[M] It's a 'Ketchup' bottle.  [S] Exactly.
And, I started to ask him, I said, "What, what does this mean?"
[M] I'm trying to figure out if you were a troll teacher?

[S] Well, no because like this means something, I don't know 
 like Rock Paper Scissors? You know, paper beats rock.

Anyhow, they said, "You know, teacher. 'You know' time." Well, now 'you know' 
 time, but like, "You know, teacher. You know what this is."

And I finally clued in, I'm like, "Oh!!! You mean like, like this, like finger..." Ah, that's 
 so wrong, but like this is the motion that people usually do, to which they responded,
"This, teacher, no. This, teacher no. Original."

And I don't really understand how original, the word 
 original, applies to this motion right here.

[M] It's some kind of new game they're playing with each other.
[S] 
 This is original style for some reason. I don't know.

But, from now on, whenever I hear the word 
 original, it's been totally ruined for me.

[M] The two of us will be at like a serious 
 meeting, and someone says the words, "An original idea."

And the two of us are under the table going...
(Sexy intoxication music)
Thank you, students for ruining a very good word.

[M] Anyhow, onto a nonsexual related conversation that I had with someone. When 
 I was still teaching, I went to a couple of open classes.

An open class is when you go to another 
 foreign teacher's school, you watch them teach,
and you meet other foreign teachers, and you get to know different teaching styles.

At the time, I was like the only outgoing girl that was there. 
 Everyone was pretty quiet. No one really had anything to say.

So, once the class was over, I kind of 
 like shuffled away to join everyone else.
We went downstairs to get some food in the cafeteria.

So, we go downstairs for food, and I sitting 
 at a table with my other foreign friends,
and there's one open space in front of me.

Suddenly, out of the blue, this VP from another school sits down right 
 in front of me, puts down her tray, and says to me,

"My face is uneven." [S] How? What do you even say after 
 that?
Like, I have an itchy armpit. [M] I, I don't even...

[M] I don't know. Anyways, I didn't really know what to say, so 
 I was just kind of like, Oh. Oh, I don't understand.

And then she went on to say, "Your face is not uneven. 
 Your face is very beautiful, but my face is uneven."

[S] I just want to know if she 
 learned that from a conversational book.

Like, here are your different options, you can say: Hi, how are you? Hey, 
 do you come around here often? Or, hi, my face is uneven?

[M] Now, the only thing I can think of, is maybe there is 
 some kind of Korean equivalent phrase that she was translating into English.

[S] Like an idiom? [M] That's exactly what I mean. [S] Like 
 the grass grows greener on the other side, in English,
while in Korea they're like, my face is uneven.

I don't know Korean idioms very well. [M] That's 
 really the only thing I could think of.

[S] But to this day, nobody has explained 
 to Martina why their face is uneven.
So, that's it for this TL;DR.

If you have a question for next TL;DR, 
 leave it in the google moderator page.
[M] Or, check out the questions already asked,
and you can vote them up or you can vote them down.
[S] And don't forget to subscribe for more TL:DRs.
[M] Simon? [S] Yes, love.
[M] I meant to tell you this earlier, but... [S] Okay.
[M] Your face... [S] is beautiful? [M] it's uneven. I'm really sorry, hunny.

(Sad piano music) (Simon crying) [M] I'm really, 
 I don't know what to tell you.

[S] Why would you say that to me on television?
[M] Yep, it's uneven.

But, I still love you with your uneven face. You're 
 like a rhombus... shifted off to the side.
(Gong and sexy "Intoxication" music) Thanks for watching EYK's TL;DR!

title: TL;DR - The Most Awkward Conversations We Ever Had in Korea

comments.text:
Oh, my goodness! I was laughing so hard that I sounded like I was sobbing… 
and not just ordinary sobbing, but sobbing inconsolably!
About the uneven face comment:
As far as I know, it's pretty common throughout all Asian cultures to 
compliment others by belittling one's self. Actually, girls in the west do 
it a lot too, so it shouldn't be an alien concept.
I think part of why your wedding ring didn't convince the old man is 
because in South Korea (and Japan), trendy young women seem to like wearing 
rings on their lefthand ring finger when they're not married.﻿

comments.text:
I think that Korean was maybe referring to Korean phrase 얼굴이 반반하다. It 
normally means that 'you got a beautiful face' but since 반 also means 
'half', it could be translated as 'you got a face with equal even halves.' 
It's a little of a stretch here but I think only way I can think why Korean 
teacher emphasized evenness of faces so much times.﻿

I suddenly came up with this after watching this video a few times :D﻿

comments.author: Erie Chung

comments.text:
3:57 Omg this is so funny and iteresting! Here in Brazil we do this hand 
gesture when something bad happens/is about to happen. We only do this with 
friends, at least I don't feel confortable doing this in front of people 
that I don't know very well. Example: You take an F on a test. *Does the 
sign*. 
Note: It is kinda vulgar to do this sing if you aren't talking to a close 
person. 

It's funny how different some cultures can be, and I love to learn more 
about these things! ♥ ﻿

comments.text:
Humans tend to think even faces or at least close to even symmetry of the 
face and body is attractive as it's a sign that you're healthy and 
therefore likely to produce healthy children. She was basically saying the 
girl talk equivalent of "You're so pretty, I'm not near as pretty as you" 
but in a scientific manner.﻿

comments.author: herzy vordor

comments.text:
Oh well I am pretty sure she was talking about face proportions when she 
said her face is uneven. In Korea, it's considered very lucky to have an 
'even' or 'proportional' face, where everything simply... looks right, i 
guess?
It's like, your nose doesn't override everything because it's so huge, or 
your lips aren't too wide or too small, your eyes aren't too far apart and 
etc.
It's very symmetrical, is kind of the gist. It's just a very nice face, 
really. Having an uneven face basically means it's un-proportionate ratios 
and such.... XD LOL.
I'm almost totally sure that's what she meant, so basically what she was 
trying to say was that you have a very beautiful face. In korean, telling 
someone they have a proportional face is simply a compliment on how nice 
each feature compliments the others.﻿
